> I do have to wonder though, does anyone make use of the Assert class' 
> static nature?  (Let's restrict the responses to all the 'nays' rather 
> than the 'yays.')  I've only used asserts through JUnit's TestCase.

Having a "static" way to access assert functionality is important as soon as
you factor out behaviour from your test case class to other classes. This
can happen e.g. 
(1) when you have common test code which cannot live in a single hierarchy.
(2) when you build mock objects.

Alternatively one could delegate the asserts back to the test case instance
or provide a default instance of test case - Assert.getInstance() - to access
those methods but what's the point? Vladimir's question has not been
answered yet: When and why should assert methods *not* be static?

Johannes
